title: Mum dying of brain cancer ‘no longer ill enough’ for PIP payments
text:
Single mum Kathy Hall, who has cancer, has her benefits cut off (Picture: SWNS)

A mum dying of brain cancer had her benefits slashed after the DWP told her she no longer qualifies for financial support.

Kathy Hall, 44, was diagnosed two-and-a-half years ago with a grade four tumour following complaints of headaches and lapses in consciousness during a trip to Wales.

An MRI scan revealed her brain was being crushed by fluid which had to be drained off before an operation removing 95 per cent of the tumour.

She said the little money she did receive in Personal Independence Payments (PIP) let her enjoy precious time with her son.

But now Ms Hall says she has been left a prisoner in her own home after her entitlement was revoked.

Kathy Hill with her son Luke Godden, 17 (Picture: SWNS)

Kathy, from Derbyshire, told the Buxton Advertiser: ‘I was given between six months and a year to live.

Advertisement

‘I had daily radiotherapy at The Christie in Manchester for six weeks as well as rounds of chemotherapy.

‘I’m a very strong person and I refused to let it beat me.’

Her £140-per-week PIP payments were stopped back in August following a reassessment by the Department for Work and Pensions who said they needed to reflect a change in her prognosis.

‘That money may not have been much but I’m dying of cancer and it gave me the freedom to make some memories with my son,’ Kathy said.

‘Now it has been taken away from me I am a prisoner in my own home and I am losing the fight in me.’

Kathy Hall has now been judged fit to work (Picture: SWNS)

A DWP spokesperson said: ‘We’re committed to ensuring disabled people and those with health conditions get the support they’re entitled to.

‘Decisions about PIP entitlement are made based on information provided, including from a GP or medical specialist.

‘Where a claimant disagrees after a review they can submit a further appeal to a free independent tribunal.

‘Ms Hall continues to receive support through Universal Credit.’
